ETYMOLOGY: From Middle English claspen, likely from a Germanic root related to Old English clyppan ('to embrace, clasp').

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: transitive verb: takes a direct object
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To grasp or hold (something or someone) tightly with one's hand or arms.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 紧握；紧抱；紧抓（某物或某人）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: She clasped her hands together in prayer.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: transitive verb: takes a direct object
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To fasten something with a clasp or similar device.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He clasped the necklace around her neck.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他把项链扣在她脖子上。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A device, typically metal, for fastening things together.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The clasp on my bracelet is broken.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: She felt the firm clasp of his hand.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 她感受到了他手的紧握。
